docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''When the Cure Is Not Worth the Cost'' (Op-Ed, April 11), Maia Szalavitz says ''providing equal coverage for mental and physical illnesses sounds like a good idea,'' but only if ''mental health parity is tied to evidence-based treatment.''

headline.main: A New Deal for the Mentally Ill

docs.abstract: Six letters respond to Maia Szalavitz April 11 Op-Ed calling for evidence-based mental health treatment; Dr Richard Gromberg says as psychiatrist, he needs flexibility to fit treatment to individual's needs; Milton Spett says mental health parity law would do more good than harm; Dr Lisa Wiseman says if only proven treatments are covered by insurance, then there will be no new treatments; Mimi Barron says parity would bring huge increase in costs, with increasing numbers of people identified as having mental illness; Michael M Gindi says clinicians often must try several different treatments until most effective one is found; Prof Sidney J Blatt says effort to identify evidence-based treatments is misguided because it focuses on techniques rather than on therapeutic relationship; drawing

docs.lead_paragraph: One-fifth of the workers who build housing in New York City work off the books, according to a study to be released on Sunday.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Russell Sage Foundation, which will celebrate its centennial this week, has managed to quantify populations that are difficult to count.

docs.lead_paragraph: I wish Ann Hulbert (April 1) had examined in greater detail the central dilemma of the intellectually daring citizens of the People’s Republic of China. Those who would like to make a difference in today’s China also know how dangerous free expression can be. How does one think outside the box when the simplest questions are dangerous?.

docs.lead_paragraph: Jonathan Cohn's article (April 1) gives us reason to be optimistic, but lest we become prematurely giddy about the possibility that the left and right can unite in a common cause for universal health care, we need to remember there are 1,001 trapdoors in Congress through which any proposal may fall. And there will still be plenty of special-interest groups around to pull the levers.

headline.main: What's the One Thing Big Business and the Left Have In Common?

docs.abstract: April 1 article on growing corporate support for universal health care prompts letters from Michael R Meacham, Oliver Fein and Leonard Rodberg and Mike Butterfield

docs.lead_paragraph: It is possible to get many things at the Four Seasons Hotel in Westlake Village, Calif., but a blood-and-urine panel that analyzes the condition of your DNA is a relatively new development. The panel, offered through the California WellBeing Institute as part of several luxury-lifestyle packages, including a $2,800 executive physical, is boomingly popular: about 50 people signed up in January, the first month it was available.
docs.abstract: Some high-end spas are offering DNA analysis as ultimate and most intimate evolution in personalized care; many offer recommendations or products based on variations in certain genes; while there is little proof that such personalized products can make difference, it makes sense that they might, given thousands of subtle variations in genetic functions that affect health and aging; clinical relevance of such testing discussed; photo (L)
